data.title: Debugger fails silently (Python)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu Mate 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a Hello World Python program, with a syntax error. 
2. Make sure the Debug Console is closed. 
3. Press F5 to start debugger

Get this notification at the top:

> [Error] Debug adapter process has terminated unexpectedly      [Close]

_If the Debug Console is open, sometimes (not every time) it shows the syntax error_

data.title: Debugger stopped working (context python)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu Mate 16.04 LTS

Error Text:

> Traceback (most recent call last):
> 
> >   File "/tmp/tmp-158678DPRC7D7mLdu/visualstudio_py_debugger.py", line 1646, in loop cmd()
> >   File "/tmp/tmp-158678DPRC7D7mLdu/visualstudio_py_debugger.py", line 1918, in command_execute_code
> >    thread.run_on_thread(text, cur_frame, eid, frame_kind, repr_kind)
> >   File "/tmp/tmp-158678DPRC7D7mLdu/visualstudio_py_debugger.py", line 1246, in run_on_thread
> >    self.schedule_work(lambda : self.run_locally(text, cur_frame, execution_id, frame_kind, repr_kind))
> >   File "/tmp/tmp-158678DPRC7D7mLdu/visualstudio_py_debugger.py", line 1238, in schedule_work
> >    self.unblock()
> >   File "/tmp/tmp-158678DPRC7D7mLdu/visualstudio_py_debugger.py", line 1234, in unblock
> >    self._block_lock.release()
> > RuntimeError: release unlocked lock

Steps to Reproduce: (_was working properly, no idea why it stopped_)
1. Try to debug a simple Hello World Python program (press F5 to start)
2. press F11 to Step-Into (error occurs right at the first line)

Tried deleting all /tmp/tmp-\* files & directories (there were a huge number). Also found a number of /tmp/vscode-\* directories. Deleted them as well and restarted vscode. Error persists.

data.title: Expanding debug variables
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version:10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce: when debugging, there is an extra mouse click to open my variables. it would be nice if there were a keyboard shortcut or (better) if the variables were expanded by default.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ttB2hH5vsdU&feature=youtu.be

if you look at this vid. expanding variables can get tedious after a while

data.title: c# syntax highlighting parameter named 'value' improperly
Move working file model shutdown to DoShutdown phase.
data.body: Fix #5912 . Postpone `workingFilesModel.shutdown` from `beforeShutdown` phase to `ShutDown` phase of TextFileServices, as `ShutDown` phase is used for UI state persistence.

data.title: Word wrapping turns automatically on and can't be turned off
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create new file
2. Type a string longer than 300 characters - let's say 310 times character 'a'
3. Create new file (using ctrl+n)
4. Return to the first file (using ctrl+tab)
5. The line you've just typed is now wrapped on viewport width. "Toggle Word Wrap" command does not have any effect until you restart the VS Code.

data.title: Intellisense, navigation (ctrl+click) stops working for react-native projects
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-insider
- OS Version: 10.10.5

In a react-native project, in this issue https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/3099#issuecomment-163567498 it is suggested to follow this steps in order to avoid `../../../../..` paths in requires:

package.json:

``` json
{
  "name": "@whatever"
}
```

(or without `@` it works too)
Then in your files you can load a package like this:

``` javascript
import MyComponent from '@whatever/components/myComponent';
```

The problem with this is that navigation (ctrl+click), intellisense, etc. stops working

data.title: Not responding PHP
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
Open PHP files
Few minutes later appears "Not Responding" message

data.title: Can't start as normal user on Arch Linux

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0 and 1.1.0
- OS Version: Arch Linux x64

VSCode doesn't start, either from a shortcut or the terminal when launched as a normal user. The insider version works as sudo, but not as a normal user. The GUI doesn't appear and the process must be killed manually. Launching it with the --verbose option generates a blank output.

Things I've tried:

Manual install & from the AUR package
.config and .vscode folders have the correct permissions
Using electron's --enable-logging and --v=10 gives different outputs for a normal (failing) launch and a sudo (correct) launch:

Results in hang:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5404052/14935294/43393f5e-0ecc-11e6-958c-1fbe6a9a9e69.png)

Works as expected:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5404052/14935303/86460cb4-0ecc-11e6-83db-d0b2a96378ac.png)

p.s. Previous installer worked fine on centos 7.

data.title: Allow to set CSS for the editor background

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.title: Prefer type `any` to `number` for thread ids in debug protocol
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

The debug protocol identifies threads with a unique `number`, but in some languages (e.g., on the JVM) threads are identified by names using a string. It would be more flexible if the debug protocol used `any` instead of `number` to reference threads.

data.title: Copy in File Explorer does not paste into Code Explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Right click > copy or Ctrl+C a file in File Explorer
2. Go to Code, Right click > Paste or Ctrl+V in Explorer

Actual:
Nothing happens unless you already copied a file in Code, then it will paste that instead.

I read some other issues similar to this, but I'm wondering why dragging files from File Explorer into Code works and this doesn't. I'm guessing an Electron issue?

data.title: View full size images and allow image zoom
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a large image

By default the image is scaled down to fit the screen with no options to zoom or to see the full resolution image. It would be a nice feature and is supported in other editors.

data.title: Window is not responding at random
data.body:

- OS Version: Windows 10

Not sure of the repro steps since I was not doing anything similar the few times this has happened. I do have this error in the Developer Tools console:

![loggingwarning](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/14932181/58595a2c-0e27-11e6-9ae1-6836bee27378.PNG)

data.title: Unknown locale value falls back to English, not OS locale
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.0-insiders
- OS Version:Windows 8.1 FRA

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install VS Code on French Windows OS
2. Launch VS Code, without a locale.json, the display language is French
3. Configure language to create a locale.json.  Prepopulated value is "fr"
4. Change "fr" to nonsense value like "fx"
5. Restart VS Code, now display language is English

Should unknown locale values fall back to OS locale to have the same behavior as when there is no locale set?

data.title: { "moduleResolution": "node" } support incomplete; doesn't understand package.json files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.3

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create the following project structure.
2. Open the root folder in VS Code.
3. Observe errors and poor Intellisense in ./src/entry.js.

It appears that the "Node module resolution" support in VS Code is incomplete, and only understands two variants:
- how to resolve a single [file as a module](https://nodejs.org/api/modules.html#modules_file_modules) (e.g., ./src/node_modules/foo.ts),
- how to resolve a [folder as a module](https://nodejs.org/api/modules.html#modules_folders_as_modules) that contains an "index" file (e.g., ./src/node_modules/bar/index.ts).

It doesn't understand the third variant:
- how to resolve a [folder as a module](https://nodejs.org/api/modules.html#modules_folders_as_modules) that contains a "package" file (e.g., ./src/node_modules/baz/package.json pointing to ./src/node_modules/baz/main.ts).

All three of these variants (in any mixture) are _vital_ to proper support for "Node module resolution" in modular Node project structures.

Also, _none_ of these variants work when the file extensions are .js instead of .ts (even when using a jsconfig.json file or allowJs=true).  This is terrible, and makes VS Code useless for navigating many existing Javascript projects.  The fact than any of the variants work for .ts files is great, but they should definitely work for .js files!

**./tsconfig.json**

```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "module": "es6",
        "moduleResolution": "node"
    }
}
```

**./src/entry.ts**

```
import foo from 'foo'; // OK
import bar from 'bar'; // OK
import baz from 'baz'; // [ts] Cannot find module 'baz'.

foo.foo(); // has Intellisense
bar.bar(); // has Intellisense
baz.baz(); // does not have Intellisense
```

**./src/node_modules/foo.ts**

```
export function foo(x: string) {}
```

**./src/node_modules/bar/index.ts**

```
export function bar(y: number) {}
```

**./src/node_modules/baz/package.json**

```
{
    "name": "baz",
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "main": "./main.ts"
}
```

**./src/node_modules/baz/main.ts**

```
export function baz(z: boolean) {}
```

data.title: Deleting a folder in Code that is open in another instance does nothing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder
2. Open a new window a directory above the already open folder
3. Delete the originally opened folder in the new instance

It hangs for a few seconds, then removes the folder from the explorer but does not move it to the recycle bin and effectively does nothing. No warnings or errors. Refreshing the folder just relists it in explorer.

data.title: locale.json IntelliSense shows "zh-tw", should be "zh-TW"
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.0.0-alpha
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. ConfigureLanguage
2. Try IntelliSense with "zh"
Shows as zh-CH but zh-tw.

data.title: Reopen Closed File for closed New File shows invalid resource error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a new window (with no folder open)
2. Remove Untitled-1 from Working Files
3. File > Open Recent > Reopen Closed File (or Ctrl+Shift+T)

![reopenuntitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/14926297/518eeeea-0e00-11e6-9877-0c27d1bc4a22.PNG)

It only shows the error the first time you try to reopen the file.

data.title: [snippets] prefix not matching forward slashes
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1
- OS Version: win7

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Create a snippet for the sass language: 

```
"docblock": {
        "prefix": "///",
        "description": "Creates a simple sassdoc block.",
        "body": [
            "/// $1",
            "///",
            "$2"
        ]
    },
```
1.  Open up a sass file and try the snippet

However it never matches. I tried escaping them as well but to no avail. Are forward slashes not recognized?

data.title: Auto updater for mac
data.body: I have noticed there is not an auto updater for mac.  I have coded one up and would be willing to share.  What are yalls plans for updates for mac?  The way this one works that I wrote is you just pull down the zip file and you gotta open the zip file and drag the new app into Applications.

data.title: [folding] support golang multiline strings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10-insider
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start a golang project.
2. Create a function in the form:

``` go
func foo() {
    bar := `
this is a multiline string.
`
}
```

Try and collapse `func foo() {` and the multiline string is not collapsed with it.
